parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>False. There is no CMF number present in the post.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>True. The post refers to "Primarul Sigheti," implicitly referencing a specific candidate, although not by full name.  The post also explicitly mentions "Ioan Turcin," who is the author and a local councilor, but this is not in the context of a parliamentary election.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>True. The post is a paid Facebook advertisement, inherently designed to reach a wide audience. The content addresses issues relevant to the residents of Paulis commune.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>Partially True. While the post doesn't directly advocate for or against a specific candidate in the parliamentary elections, it aims to influence public opinion regarding the actions of "Primarul Sigheti," potentially impacting their electoral prospects in future local elections. The objective is not directly related to the parliamentary elections, but it has a political objective.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>Partially True. The post presents information about local council decisions, but it does so in a highly opinionated and accusatory manner, going beyond objective reporting. It could be considered a form of citizen journalism, but it lacks the neutrality expected of journalistic reporting.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>Partially True. While expressing a personal opinion, the post's accusatory tone and the use of a paid Facebook advertisement suggest an intention to influence public perception, exceeding the bounds of a simple personal opinion.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>579099107818696</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The Facebook post, while not directly advocating for or against a parliamentary candidate, engages in political commentary that could indirectly influence voters' perceptions of local officials. The accusatory tone and paid advertisement format suggest an attempt to shape public opinion, which could have electoral consequences in future local elections.  However, it does not directly violate Article 98 t) as it does not explicitly promote or discourage voting for a specific candidate in the current parliamentary elections. The post focuses on local politics and the actions of a local official, not the parliamentary candidates.  The image attached is not directly related to the text and does not add to the electoral propaganda aspect.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>FALSE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates>
  <candidate><name>Primarul Sigheti</name><impact>NEGATIVE</impact></candidate>
  <candidate><name>Ioan Turcin</name><impact>POSITIVE (indirectly)</impact></candidate>
</electoral-propaganda-candidates>
<responsible-party-or-group>INDEPENDENT</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police>
</message-for-police>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
